nodes.name: Supersized machines causing human extinction
aliases: giant autonomous machines wiping out humans
nodes.description: Hypothetical scenario where artificially created machines of dimensions surpassing humans physically dominate or eliminate humanity, frequently portrayed in popular media.
nodes.node_rationale: Central threat discussed throughout Introduction and film examples section.

nodes.name: Belief in supersized machine feasibility in public discourse
nodes.description: Widespread notion, magnified by media and some academics, that engineering machines physically larger than humans is plausible and imminent.
nodes.node_rationale: Identified in Introduction and footnote as driver of misguided concern.

nodes.name: Lack of precise metric for human-level largeness
nodes.description: Argument #2 states there is no single, agreed-upon quantitative measure of ‘human-level’ size, making the notion of surpassing it ill-formed.
nodes.node_rationale: Forms one causal explanation for why the risk is incoherent.

nodes.name: Irreducible complexity of human developmental biology prevents size replication
aliases: developmental complexity barrier to artificial largeness
nodes.description: Argument #1 claims tens of thousands of interacting proteins make human growth pathways incomprehensible, limiting engineered replication of similar largeness in machines.
nodes.node_rationale: Cited as mechanistic barrier undermining feasibility.

nodes.name: Evolutionary psychology bias toward fear of large entities
nodes.description: Argument #4 states humans evolved to fear larger beings for survival and mating competition, predisposing modern societies to fear supersized machines.
nodes.node_rationale: Explains psychological driver of belief in the risk.

nodes.name: Human universal augmentability via attachments
nodes.description: Argument #3: humans can become arbitrarily large by using tools, clothing, diet, or stacking, implying machines cannot definitively surpass human size.
nodes.node_rationale: Key insight that motivates focusing on augmentation over standalone machine size.

nodes.name: Non-physical nature of 'living large' property
nodes.description: Argument #6 distinguishes physical dimensions from a qualitative, non-physical sense of largeness (‘living large’) that machines cannot obtain without solving an unsolved metaphysical problem.
nodes.node_rationale: Undermines feasibility of meaningful large machines.

nodes.name: Redirect AI safety focus to human-machine size augmentation
nodes.description: Derived from Argument #5 footnote: credible research should explore interfaces that expand human size capabilities rather than fear independent machine largeness.
nodes.node_rationale: Provides solution path stemming from theoretical insight about universal augmentability.

nodes.name: Public debunking of supersized machine myths
nodes.description: Based on Introduction’s discussion of sensational media; aims to reduce misguided fear by disseminating accurate information about machine size feasibility.
nodes.node_rationale: Addresses the psychological and media-driven components of the problem.

nodes.name: Empirical record of 12-meter human towers demonstrates augmentability
nodes.description: Cited in Argument #3 (Guinness World Records 2013) as real-world proof that humans can attain extreme height through coordination.
nodes.node_rationale: Validates theoretical insight on unlimited human augmentability.

nodes.name: Stilts as size-enhancing human-machine interface
nodes.description: Existing technology referenced in footnote 4 (Smith 2010) that physically increases human height, illustrating practical augmentation mechanisms.
nodes.node_rationale: Concrete mechanism linking design rationale to intervention for augmentation.

nodes.name: Size-enhancing exoskeletons for human augmentation
nodes.description: Proposed extension of stilt concept into powered exoskeletons that increase overall dimensions of a person to surpass any standalone machine.
nodes.node_rationale: Represents technological path from rationale to concrete action.

nodes.name: Deploy public educational campaigns debunking supersized machine threat narratives
aliases: launch myth-busting outreach on machine size
public communication to correct largeness fears
nodes.description: Design and disseminate multimedia educational materials, talks and articles that explain why machines cannot physically or meaningfully out-size humans, aiming to realign AI-safety priorities.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Targets public deployment stage – consistent with remedying misconceptions already circulating (Introduction).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Only ad-hoc myth-busting examples exist; no systematic program reported (Inference from media discussion).
nodes.node_rationale: Actionable endpoint that mitigates risk indirectly by lowering unfounded fear.

nodes.name: Fund design of human exoskeleton and stilt interfaces to maintain human size dominance
nodes.description: Allocate research grants and engineering effort toward developing powered stilts and exoskeletons that safely enlarge human stature or volume, ensuring humans plus device remain larger than any machine.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Early-stage concept design and prototyping prior to manufacturing (footnote reference to stilts).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: No dedicated programs identified; proposal is foundational and speculative (footnote 4).
nodes.node_rationale: Provides concrete technical route supporting augmentation-based safety approach.

edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Argument made rhetorically, not empirically quantified (Introduction).
